item.title: Week 5: A mirror of life
item.description:
Staring into the eyes of a tiny spider is quite haunting.

Hello!

This square meter plot is a battleground of life. I see relentless pursuit of survival; each bug for its own. Brutal. Each adopted evolutionarily to be specialist in certain ways, to be efficient hunter. Poetic.

Well, a month went by, and here we are. I have already seen a lot. Courting, mating, caring, and killing.

Circle of life, eh?

’Til next week!

item.title: Week 4: Dust on the sensor
item.description:
I see bugs in my dreams now.

Hello!

The ant-mimicking spiders have been the highlight of this week(one, two and three). I saw three different varieties, and each time they fooled me for a few moments. There are incredible theories about how they evolved into such convincing mimics.

I stepped out at night a few times this week with a headlamp to observe the plot. Night photography is really hard without the right equipment, but spotting the paddy field frog was quite nice.

The plot’s undergrowth is drying up, and I can now more or less see the soil easily, unlike the last few weeks.

Another unexpected thing is that the plot is becoming an island of greenery because of all my movement around it. The immediate surrounding has become dry. I can’t think of a way to avoid this for now.

’Til next week!

item.title: Week 3: Settling in
item.description:
Oh it's a bug's life for me

Hello!

The flies from Tephritidae family have a funky dating process. Check it out here. I had to push myself a bit to record all of the footage over 3.5 hours. It was quite fascinating to see the whole thing happening.

Otherwise, the patch is still green, and quite a few varieties of bugs are still around. I think I have seen five or six different species that I haven't been able to get a decent picture of yet. So, fingers crossed!

’Til next week!

item.title: Week 2: Ants marching
item.description:
I have started talking to bugs.

Hello!

Did you know that ants do not trigger the touch-me-not plant’s defense mechanism? So cool!

Well, would you look at that stats page, so many numbers! I think I have documented quite a lot of “resident” bugs, and now the number of new species I encounter might start to decrease.

If you are planning to start a similar project, make sure you do not pick a plot right below a coconut tree. The plot I selected, however, is right beneath one. The tree’s branches look like they are ready to fall at any moment. So, this bug documentation project has turned into an adventure sport!

Note to self: Be graceful in your movements. Do not spook the bugs.

’Til next week!

item.title: Week 1: Not bad!
item.description:
My knees hurt.

Hello!

So, end of the week (well, just 4 days)! 20 species found, from very tiny to slightly bigger ones!

I saw 3 new hoppers that I hadn't seen before. They are tiny!

So, the morning light is not enough to get good quality photos, I have to bump up ISO, which leads to very grainy images. Looks like I will spend monies on a flash. Sigh.

My macro photography skills have rusted. I am hoping it will get better as the time goes on.

I also discoverd a very similar project done before by Chris Helzer. Read about it here. The photographs he has taken are very clean and precise! Now I have a benchmark to aim for!

One week at a time!

item.title: Day one!
item.description:
So it begins.

Hello world!

Welcome to a square meter project, here we like bugs. Find more about the project in the about section.

Today, I set up the fence posts on 4 corners of the patch, cleaned up the space a bit, placed an old wood piece in it. That is it. No more fiddling with the patch for the rest of the year.

My first immediate dilemma is this:

If I spot a bug within the square meter but it moves out of the boundary before I can get a photo, should I still take the picture and count it as a sighting, or should I let it go?
